Comment: You are right. But it's easier for people to relate to and understand 2008 as a comparison because that's something that most of us have actually been through and have living memory of.    Many Gen Z'ers remember being kids and their parents suddenly having to sell their family homes, downgrade spaces and live on less to survive. They remember their parents coming home jobless, struggling to find work or having to switch schools to cheaper ones, leaving their friends behind. 2008 up-ended many peoples childhoods. And the millennials & Gen X's Etc were the young adults who had to literally work through and survive that world.    But I think 2008 will have nothing on the current coming times in terms of hardships for everyone.

Author: Creative_Recover

Comment: If Depressions took down monopolists there'd be no such thing as "Old Money". But the reality is that your super-rich will absolutely find a way to survive (and maybe even flourish, as has been witnessed so far- billionaire wealth has been growing) through these trying times.    If the dollar loses is value as a currency, then there's a chance that it could make American products more competitive on the world trading stage. But you're talking about becoming the next Vietnam or something here; the economic miracle that occurred in post-war America wasn't simply down to mass production and a weaker dollar but rather it had a lot to do with the post-war economies that most countries were experiencing back then and how America more precisely stimulated its economy out of that environment.    America may want to go back to the past, but other countries don't. We don't have the same problems as you and if we can find a way to create a less US dollar-focused world, we absolutely will. Most economists inside and outside of America unanimously agree that Trump's tariff plans are not going to end well and we don't want you taking us down with you, not least because we most of all didn't vote for any this.    I really don't like to sound so negative, but I don't see many silver linings to this situation.
Author: Creative_Recover
